turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Sozin's Comet.
turn.1: What was the critical reception of Sozin's Comet?
turn.2: Susan Stewart, reviewing for "The New York Times", praised the show's effort at philosophizing, noting that "this is complicated stuff, the reconciliation of religion and violence, and it’s beautifully rendered: simple enough for Nickelodeon fans and subtle enough for their parents, with humor to puncture the pomposity inherent in the heroic genre." "Sozin's Comet" has received its share of criticism as well.
turn.3: What criticism did Sozin's Comet receive?
turn.4: Reviewers commented about the difficulty in understanding the voice of a new character: the Lion Turtle.
turn.6: The Lion Turtle was designed by Bryan Konietzko and character designer Jae Woo Kim.
turn.7: Did anyone else have criticisms of the show?
turn.8: Konietzko disliked how the Lion Turtle turned out; he felt that the art was not up to standards of the original design he had received.
turn.9: What other criticisms did the show receive?
turn.10: CraveOnline felt that because "the series was for children, the writers were at a loss of ideas to work around the murder angle," and the decision not to kill the Fire Lord introduced "so many convenient plot twists [that] set us up for a humongous deus ex machina that allows the Fire Lord to be thwarted without dying".
turn.11: What else was notable about the reception?
turn.12: The premiere of "Sozin's Comet" averaged 5.6 million viewers, 195% more viewers than Nickelodeon had received in mid-July 2007. During the week of July 14, 2008, it ranked as the most-viewed program for the under-14 demographic.
